title: What are the benefits of writing poetry? - Quora

response.answer_text: POETRY An empty heart can never write a poem. Be it gladness, sadness or madness it has to be there in the poet while he writes. It comes out when we are brimming with emotions and feel a little friction inside An itching of the Heart, maybe. And just when we start to scratch there with the tip of our pen, the heart of the poet just begins to flow in a continuous manner till it empties from within. And so we end up with a poem, the stronger the itching, the more heavily it flows out from within. Poetry is sensations in pure sense. We feel, we write, we put it on a display to let other emphasize with the way we are feeling. And so poets are by default sensitive to live up to the very definition of a poet. Poetry may have wisdom but it isn’t mandatory. We aren’t intellectual beings we are sensitive beings. By saying this I didn’t mean that we are cry babies or childish in any sense. It’s just that we feel more vividly. And we choose to write about those incidents where we find that itching along with the emotions. So that itching is the very thing that inspires us to write, we get to feel when a poem is going to come out of us. That itching magnifies our ability to feel in the very moments when we write. We feel a blast of a mixture of emotions in those moments. With these raw powerful emotions, our poetry is cooked. In a poem we feel every word of what we write. BENEFITS OF WRITING POETRY:- 1) It’s healthy to write poetry: It’s a way to vent out the excess of emotions. For ex:- Just imagine you had a fight with your colleague in your office. You came back home with your head loaded with all the frustrations, like a balloon ready to burst. Chances are high that you would end up screaming at the top of your lungs at your loved ones for trivial reasons and would later on regret doing the same. So it’s better to vent out all that frustration you had in the mind by scribbling a few lines. Your excess emotions would subside and you would feel your shit in control again. Do it if not for yourself but atleast for your loved ones Before losing your mind, lose your heart! 2) Poetry is healing: Poetry is healing in a way that, we write to better understand ourselves when we write we have we revisit that particular incident through our imaginations and memories and with heightened sensations we try to feel what happened, more vividly. Poetry is an emotional response of what happens with us good, bad or ugly. And by writing the same we get over that incident by releasing the supressed feelings of that time. And that’s how we heal. 3) We become better humans:­- Humanity is to serve other humans. We develop an increased ability to get into other people’s shoe. We develop understanding. We become kind. It has been rightly said by Cristopher Marlow in his play Dr Faustus that It’s a comfort in wretchedness to have companions in woe. Even when the poet is not wretched he can relate to other people’s pain and feel comfort for himself. It maybe out of empathy as well. 4) Pleasure of the senses:- It can’t be argued that all the pleasure of the world is through our 5 senses only. Be it touch, taste, sound, smell. A Poet being a sensitive person has heightened state of all these senses and so he feels soaring highs and excruciating hues and cries, depending upon his emotional responses to what happens to him.

Writing poetry is a way to grow emotionally and intellectually, as language articulates and frames experience symbolically. Writing poetry is also a natural process, serving people’s innate need to explain themselves and their lives in the world (a desire that is particularly strong during adolescence). Writing poetry produces a concrete product that is a source of pride and that can be recognized. Writing poetry is a vehicle for expressing altruistic values and philosophical explorations about life’s meaning. And writing poetry is a free and available resource that can be used for self-exploration, gratification, and healing for a lifetime. Poetry provides a cultural context and expressive model that supports openness and emotional honesty. People who write poetry exercise insight and sensitivity, sometimes in profound and illuminating ways. The act of creating poetry reinforces ego strengths, including realizations about who I am, what I think, what my life has been like, what I want, and what I can accomplish. The act of creating poetry is joyful and self-reinforcing, even when the content is about a sad or traumatic event. People who write poetry can become more in touch with larger issues of life’s meaning and connectedness, developing a spiritual appreciation of life. The act of writing a poem is a skill that people can use to help themselves over and over again throughout a lifetime.

I think that for some people, writing poetry is cathartic - Its a way to challenge ourselves on what we think or feel, a way to 'write it out' and approach what we're experiencing in a different way. For others its an exercise in structuring words and language in interesting, quirky and challenging ways; an opportunity to be playful. For still others, poetry is a way to explore the deeper parts of ourselves and bring other aspects of our personality, circumstances or the world around. The benefits come because these things allow us to challenge our own thoughts and feelings, express ourselves and cultivate new ways of looking at things.

It's like taking a photograph with your thoughts. You record your emotions and perspective in written words. You can read your own poem later in life and remember a you and experiences that you have forgotten. When you look at a picture, you are a voyeur of your past. With a poem you are, to a far greater extent, the original protagonist. And, if you're really lucky, you capture something that others can relate to – an aspect of the human experience that helps them understand their own lives. A photo cannot not do that for a third party observer.

Poetry unleashes the mind and senses from linear perspective, while still arriving at meaning.    It reveals how unusual phrasing and metaphor can direct the creative mind into deeper insights, as well as more expansive experiencing of principles, life, moments, and self. It reveals and strengthens one's own artistic soul and unique voice.   It scratches the underbelly of the obvious and invokes often new insights born of stimulating deeper mind. It frees the mind to consider wild or fantastic relationships between words that create new synergies of comprehension.   It is a tool for realization.   It can express ideas that cannot otherwise be expressed. It is fun.

For me writing poetry is pure intellectual therapy. It can be so subjective that it allows you to express your innermost feelings but most often the reader interprets them in a totally different way.   I write in a lot of other genres but, to me, poetry is special in that it can be a total stream of consciousness with no edits. You can write a complete poem while you're in line at the grocery store or in the airport waiting for a flight.  I find writing poetry also jump starts my creativity when coming up with ideas for fiction as well.
